Robinson OSERO (MPhil)
 

Master (2023, Nairobi University, Kenya)
Research interests: As a marine biologist, I am extremely committed to learning about and protecting the different ecosystems that exist in our seas and oceans. I have been fascinated by the potential of environmental DNA (eDNA) as a strong tool for understanding marine ecosystems. I am certain that incorporating eDNA analysis into marine ecology studies can yield useful insights on marine creature biodiversity, population dynamics, and conservation. Hong Kong University of Science and Technology (HKUST) is second to none in enhancing my potential and projecting me to a record high level of marine life conservation.

title: Japanese (日本語)
text:
潮 雅之 (香港科技大学・海洋学科)
2022年9月より香港科技大学の海洋学科で研究室を運営しています。個人ページはこちら.

略歴:
1981年愛媛県生まれ、理学博士 (2010年、京都大学)
2005年にマレーシアのボルネオ島キナバル山の熱帯林で生態学研究を始め、2010年に学位を取得。その後、土壌微生物群集と生態系機能の研究などを行い、2014年頃から時系列解析と環境DNA分析を用いて生態系動態のモニタリング・動態予測の研究を始める。現在は主に海洋生態系に注目して環境DNAとデータ解析を駆使した研究を行っています。
研究キーワード:
環境 DNA、生態系動態、時系列データ解析、魚類群集、微生物群集、物質循環、メタゲノム、Reservoir Computing

問い合わせ:
大学院生・研究員の受け入れ・その他問い合わせは ushio (at) ust.hk までお願いします。 現在、海洋とその周辺環境を対象として、環境DNA分析、生態学データの統計解析、環境DNA分析と統計モデリングの統合 などの研究テーマが走っています。「環境DNAに詳しくないが統計生態に関心がある」、または、「統計に詳しくはないが環境DNA分析の新規手法開発に関心がある」、などどちらかのテーマだけでも研究可能です。 日本から大学院生としてラボに参加する場合は、英語のスコアが基準を満たしている必要がありますので、ご注意ください (こちらを御覧ください)。

title: How to join the lab
text:
Join our team!
We are seeking highly motivated students and postdocs with interests in Environmental DNA, Ecosystem Dynamic, Community Ecology, Machine Learning, and Statistical Ecology. Our primary research focus is on Coastal Ecosystem, but surrounding environments such as Freshwater Ecosystems, Open Ocean, and Mangroves are also our target.
Please check our ongoing projects for more detail.
If you are interested in, please contact ushio(at)ust.hk.


Graduate students
If you are a prospective student, please submit your application to the Fok Ying Tung Graduate School of HKUST. For more information about the application process and requirements, please refer to the following websites:

Admission requirements
How to apply?
Student visa

Several scholarship programs are available for graduate students: - Scholarships and Fees


Postdocs / Research assistants
We welcome applications from postdoctoral fellows and research assistants, although the availability of opportunities depends on our research funding. If you are interested in joining our lab in either of these roles, please contact us at ushio(at)ust.hk. Additionally, we are also open to hosting visiting scholars!

title: Research
text:
This project focuses on developing and applying an innovative community monitoring technique called environmental DNA (eDNA) analysis, which allows us to monitor and understand ecological community dynamics in nature. We have developed various eDNA techniques such as a quantitative eDNA monitoring technique (Ushio et al. 2018 Metabarcoding & Metagenomics; Ushio et al. 2023 eLife), a mammal eDNA detection method (Ushio et al. 2017 Molecular Ecology Resources), and more efficient laboratory protocols for eDNA analysis (Ushio 2019 Methods in Ecology and Evolution; Ushio et al. 2022 Environmental DNA).  



   Ecological community monitoring data can be noisy, and statistical analyses are required to extract essential information. Our research group has developed and applied various statistical methods to understand ecological community dynamics, including a method to evaluate fluctuating stability of natural ecological communities (Ushio et al. 2018 Nature), a method to detect causalities when time series data are highly synchronized (Kitayama et al. 2021 Journal of Ecology), and a novel machine learning approach that uses ecological dynamics as a computational resource (Ushio et al. 2023 Royal Society Open Science). Recently, we have proposed a unified framework for time-series based causality detection method (Osada et al. 2023 bioRxiv).  



   We are particularly interested in how these advanced statistical methods can be combined with eDNA techniques, and have already explored this intersection in several publications, including Ushio (2022) Proceedings of the Royal Society B, where we monitored a high-diversity community (>1,000 species) using the quantitative eDNA technique and analyzed interspecific interactions using nonlinear time series analytical tools. In Ushio et al. (2023) eLife, we analyzed 550 fish eDNA samples and quantified fish-fish interactions based on multispecies fish eDNA time series

title: Welcome to ushio-ecolab
text:
(Hong Kong, 2022)
We are based at the Department of Ocean Science (OCES) at the Hong Kong University of Science and Technology (HKUST).   Our research group launched in September 2022 and is currently focused on developing environmental DNA techniques and statistical methods to study marine ecosystems.
